title.value: Evaluating the effectiveness of the Smart About Meds (SAM) mobile application among patients discharged from hospital: protocol of a randomised controlled trial
title.justification: The title clearly indicates the focus of the research, which is to evaluate the effectiveness of the Smart About Meds (SAM) mobile application through a randomised controlled trial.
title.quote: Evaluating the effectiveness of the Smart About Meds (SAM) mobile application among patients discharged from hospital: protocol of a randomised controlled trial

extractions.description: This paper describes a protocol for a randomized controlled trial (RCT) to evaluate the Smart About Meds (SAM) mobile application. The application aims to improve medication adherence among patients discharged from hospitals by integrating features like pharmacist monitoring and patient notification of potentially inappropriate medications (PIMs). The study involves 3250 adult patients, stratified and randomized, with outcomes measured over a 90-day follow-up period.

type.justification: The paper outlines a protocol for a randomized controlled trial, which involves empirical research through experimentation and observation of outcomes related to the SAM mobile application.
type.quote: This protocol describes a randomised controlled trial (RCT) to evaluate SAM.

name.justification: The primary focus of the research is on using a mobile application for medication management post-hospital discharge, which falls under the domain of healthcare informatics.
name.quote: This protocol, funded by the Canadian Institutes of Health Research (grant number 470182), describes our planned randomised controlled trial (RCT) to evaluate Smart About Meds (SAM), an innovative, patient-centred medication management mobile application.

name.justification: The SAM application is a mobile health tool designed to enhance medication adherence, fitting within the mobile health research domain.
name.quote: Smart About Meds (SAM) is a pilot-­tested, patient-centred mobile application that leverages the Information–Motivation–Behavioural Skills Model to provide an array of features.

name.justification: The study aims to reduce potentially inappropriate medication use and improve medication adherence, impacting healthcare costs, which links to pharmacoeconomics.
name.quote: Targeting non­adherence while raising patient awareness to PIMs may have a synergistic effect because elimination of PIMs will reduce the number of drugs in a patient’s regimen and associated costs.
